title: Projects & Past Research Experience
text:
Over the centuries, I have devoted countless hours to deciphering and translating the ancient scripts and dialects of the various peoples of Middle-earth. My goal is to gain a deeper understanding of the cultures and histories of these peoples by studying their languages. Currently, I am working on a monograph that explores the linguistic roots of the Elvish languages. Through extensive research and analysis, I hope to shed light on the connections between the different dialects of Elvish and their origins. This project has been particularly challenging, as Elvish is a complex and nuanced language, but I am determined to see it through to completion.

The History of the War of the Ring

arXiv Preprint | Code
I am creating a comprehensive and detailed history of the conflict that goes beyond the surface-level events. By gathering information from a variety of sources, including my own memories, written accounts, and oral histories, I hope to shed new light on this important period in Middle-earth’s history and provide valuable insights into the motivations and actions of the various players involved.

title: Hey there!
text:
LinkedIn
  
  
    
     Email
  




Hey there!
My name is Alexis Heath, but Lex is just fine. I am a current 2nd year Systems Biology and Bioinformatics PhD student at Case Western Reserve University in Dr. Doug Brubaker’s lab. My research interests primarily lie in using multi-omic and network-based approaches to explore estrogen signaling in endometriosis.
I graduated summa cum laude from Bowling Green State University in May of 2023, completing a B.S. with Honors in Biology and with a minor in Chemistry. While there, through seemingly countless hours of counting cells and twiddling with finicky cultures, I somehow discovered a love for scientific research and the community.
Currently, my thesis work involves exploring the role of the cervicovaginal microbiome on local estrogen signaling in the reproductive tract as well as creating tissue- and cell-type specific nuclear estrogen receptor expression derived gene regulatory networks in endometriosis and non-disease states. I hope that this work will bring new insights to the field of endometriosis research to improve diagnostic and treatment options. Though my current work is in human health, my past research experience under Dr. Christopher Ward, Dr. George Bullerjahn, & the SULI program was in environmental microbiology, revolving around harmful algal blooms, soil microbiomes, and carbon cycling, and I’m especially grateful for their guidance.
On this website, you will find a selection of my published works, updates on my current research projects, and other tidbits about me. I invite you to explore my website and learn more about me and my work: please feel free to contact me if you have any questions or would like to discuss potential projects!

title: More About Me!
text: Outside of lab, I love spending time with my family, rock climbing, traveling, and running! My daughter was born in May 2023 (right between graduating from undergrad and starting my PhD in July 2023), and exploring the world with her and my partner is the best thing in my life – I couldn’t do science without my favorite people supporting me!

title: Projects & Past Research Experience
section: An Integrative Analysis of Nuclear Estrogen Receptor Dynamics and Cervicovaginal Microbiome Interactions in Endometriosis
text:
An Integrative Analysis of Nuclear Estrogen Receptor Dynamics and Cervicovaginal Microbiome Interactions in Endometriosis

December 2023 - Current
Endometriosis is an estrogen-dependent disease where endometrial-like tissue grows outside of the uterus. Though estimated to affect at least 1 in 10 reproductive-age women, the causes are not understood, and there are no effective treatment methods. To fill this knowledge gap, I am characterizing the relationship between cervicovaginal microbiome components and local estrogen signaling along with nuclear estrogen receptor expression-derived gene regulatory networks. Aim 1 of my study will determine cervicovaginal microbiome-derived regulators of local estrogen signaling in the endometrium. Aim 2 of my study will delineate tissue- and cell-type specific estrogen receptor isoform expression derived gene regulatory networks in people with and without endometriosis.

title: Projects & Past Research Experience
section: Risk of HSV-2 Acquisition Amongst Women with Bacterial Vaginosis: A Systematic Review with Meta-Analysis
text:
Risk of HSV-2 Acquisition Amongst Women with Bacterial Vaginosis: A Systematic Review with Meta-Analysis

February 2024 - August 2024
My role on this project was conducting the meta-analysis portion of the study, allowing us to synthesize data from multiple studies. I analyzed the pooled estimates to quantify the association between bacterial vaginosis (BV) and the risk of herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) acquisition. This involved evaluating heterogeneity across studies, performing subgroup analyses to explore potential moderators, and assessing publication bias to ensure the robustness of the findings. My work provided the quantitative foundation for the study’s conclusions and implications for public health interventions aimed at reducing sexually transmitted infection risks in women.

title: Projects & Past Research Experience
section: Role of Cervicovaginal Microbiome in Recurrent Implantation Failure
text:
Role of Cervicovaginal Microbiome in Recurrent Implantation Failure

May 2024 - Current
Recurrent Implantation Failure (RIF) is a clinical phenomenon characterized by a lack of implantation after the transfer of several embryos. This study investigates how shifts in cervicovaginal microbial composition and function may disrupt key signaling pathways, like estrogen and progesterone signaling, essential for implantation. Using scRNAseq and multi-omic data, the project seeks to identify microbial species, microbiome-derived metabolites, and microbial peptides that correlate with implantation success or failure, shedding light on potential biomarkers or therapeutic targets. This research aims to deepen our understanding of the microbiome’s systemic impact, ultimately informing interventions to improve implantation outcomes in individuals experiencing RIF.

title: Projects & Past Research Experience
section: Analyzing the Microbial Community Regime Shift in Sandusky Bay from 2018 - 2020 – Honors Thesis
text:
Analyzing the Microbial Community Regime Shift in Sandusky Bay from 2018 - 2020 – Honors Thesis

May 2022 - May 2023
I analyzed the genomics of three years of Sandusky Bay blooms at the genus level to determine the effect of varying environmental factors in one bloom’s dominance over another. The goal was to discover how varying levels of total nitrogen, total phosphorus, Secchi disk depth, and water/air temperatures affect the genotypes of algae in Sandusky Bay across a single season and year to year. I received a CURS grant from BGSU for my work on this project. The results from this experiment were presented by myself at the CURS Symposium in April 2023 and received the award for Top Oral Presentation.

title: Projects & Past Research Experience
text:
Sandusky & Springbrook Lake Monitoring Projects

January 2020 - May 2023
On the Sandusky Bay monitoring project, I assisted with multiple portions of research throughout my time on the on-going project. I ran the chlorophyll extractions for two seasons as well as the DNA processing and Total Suspended Solids collection for an additional season. I led the efforts to begin monitoring and coordinating sampling at Springbrook Lake. I handled the field work collection, processing of the chlorophyll, DNA and nutrient samples, analyzed the data, and effectively communicated my findings to the local Homeowners Association. I presented my findings at multiple meetings with the local citizen scientists, working on solutions to improve lake health in future years.

title: Projects & Past Research Experience
section: 1000 Soils Research Pilot – As a part of SULI Internship on the Molecular Observation Network (MONet)
text:
1000 Soils Research Pilot – As a part of SULI Internship on the Molecular Observation Network (MONet)

January 2022 - May 2022
During my internship at PNNL, I assisted on the 1000 Soils Pilot. This included coordinating shipments of soil samples, sieving and weighing samples, taking pH, and performing microbial biomass extractions and DNA extractions. I also took R coding classes to create visuals and run analyses on the collected data.

title: Projects & Past Research Experience
section: Impact of inorganic carbon availability on Microcystis aeruginosa growth, colony formation, uptake, and microcystin concentration.
text:
Impact of inorganic carbon availability on Microcystis aeruginosa growth, colony formation, uptake, and microcystin concentration.

May 2021 - May 2022
We selected the LE3 culture to measure the effects of two different “treatments”: pCO2 [400] representing current DIC concentrations in Lake Erie and pCO2 [1000] representing high (potential) DIC concentrations after years of acidificiation. In each treatment, there was a range of ten temperatures spanning from 18°C to 30°C (around 1.5 degrees difference between temperatures). For each temperature, six cultures were in separate 50 mL Falcon tubes to account for any contamination, and the tubes could eventually be averaged for better accuracy and precision. My primary role was to monitor and maintain the gas tanks and constant bubbling of the cultures and collect cell samples every other day. I performed all cell counts with a hemocytometer slide and analyzed all of my collected data. I received a CURS grant from BGSU for my work on the project. The results from this experiment were presented by myself at the CURS Symposium in April 2022 and by Dr. Reagan Errera at the Joint Aquatic Sciences Meeting 2022
